title: Great food, great location
text: We ate here on a Wednesday evening and had a fantastic meal. The food was excellent and the service was great, and great menu. A bit more expensive than some places we ate, but worth it for something a little bit more special. The night view of the Acropolis just topped off a lovely evening.

title: Great lunch
text: This is a great place to grab lunch after visiting the museum of ancient Greek technology or the parliament square. Serves Greek food. Perfect if you're in a hurry.

title: Great food, extensive menu
text: We had a great lunch here. There's plenty of alternatives along this road, but this restaurant has the best menu, so there's something for everyone. Food was excellent and service was great. Good value too. Recommended.

title: Great food
text: We visited Monday evening. Fantastic setting with lost of fairy lights in the trees. Food was excellent and good value. Well worth a visit.

title: Great place for lunch
text: This is tucked away in the back streets not far from the National Garden. Great food for lunch. We had their gyros menu deal - great value. Good food. Perfect for lunch.

title: Best restaurant in Athens
text: We had a fantastic meal on a Saturday night. Food fantastic. Great service. Magnificent views. Best meal we had all week. Bonus was having James Nesbitt at the table next to us!

title: Great seafood
text: This is a great place for seafood in a nice court yard setting. We had an evening meal on a Tuesday mid October during covid. The food was fantastic and the service was good, although a bit slow, but we weren't in a hurry. Would definitely recommend if you like seafood.

title: Great place for lunch after Ancient Agora
text: This was a really nice place for lunch after the Ancient Agora, or the Roman Agora. Nice and quiet. A bit off the beaten track. We visited on Tuesday mid October during covid, so it was quiet, but they didn't seem over excited to see us, but the service was good and they seemed happier once we started ordering food (there were 4 of us ). The food was great and the value was good. Would definitely recommend.

title: Hidden gem
text: This is a great place for lunch after visiting the Acropolis or the Roman Agora. It's a bit off the beaten track but we'll worth hunting out. Food was fantastic

title: Great food
text: There's a lot of restaurants along this road, but we came here based on previous reviews and we're not disappointed. The menu wasn't as extensive as others but the quality was very good and the service was very good. We had moussaka and calamari.

title: Brilliant
text: We visited on a Wednesday morning mid October during covid restrictions. We were the first ones in. They gave us a guide to explain a number of the exhibits and encourage us to get hands on with them. Some of the exhibits were fascinating, and explained some of the things we had seen earlier in the week. This museum was one of the highlights of our week and would definitely recommend it.
place: Kotsanas Museum of Ancient Greek Technology

title: Fantastic museum
text: This is the highlight of the Ancient Agora. There's a fantastic museum on the ground floor with lots of artifacts and some good explanation.

title: A must do
text: We visited on a Tuesday morning mid October during covid restrictions. Only one of the 3 entrances were open - the most northern one, not far from the Monastiraki metro station. It's free with the 30 euro pass and well worth the visit. It's a large site with lots of ruins, some in varying states of disrepair. The Stoa of Attalos is the main attraction. You can easily spend 2 hours looking around. There are plenty of places to eat nearby. We found a lovely taverna off the beaten track - Taverne Platanos.

title: Interesting neighbourhood
text: We visited on a Tuesday afternoon mid October during covid. We followed a self guided tour from the DK Athens guide book. The market is interesting - some nice leather goods. This area is less touristy and more commercial. Worth a visit if you're looking for some shopping or some souvenirs.

title: Fantastic monument
text:
This is included in the Acropolis admission. We visited on a Monday morning mid October during covid restrictions. It wasn't very busy, but we had to wear a mask whilst at the top of the Acropolis and follow a one way system, which was fine. There was plenty of space so people could explore at there own pace.
Personally, I prefered the Erechtheion to the Parthenon. Seems more elegant, more romantic. I would recommend visiting the Acropolis museum first, the day before, and getting to the Acropolis early.

title: Peaceful in the middle of a busy city
text: We spent 5 days in Athens in October during covid, and walked through the park at least 3 times, usually on the way somewhere. It's very peaceful and would be a good place to give young kids a break from archeology, or just to relax for a bit.

title: Great location for changing of the guard
text: We visited in mid October during covid restrictions. Plenty of space to watch the changing of the guard. You can get very close. It's also free, as you can't go in the mansion. Across the road is the national garden.

title: Worth a visit
text: We were on our way to the museum of ancient Greek technology and stopped off here to see the tomb of the unknown soldier and see the changing of the guards. It was a Wednesday morning mid October during covid and wasn't very busy. Personally I think watching the changing of the guards at the Presidential palace was better. There are a few places to grab something to eat around the square. It's free, so worth a visit.

title: This is a must see
text: We went here on a Sunday morning in mid October during covid restrictions, and is was almost deserted. The ruins are really good to have a look around. When we were there, the Temple of Apollon wasn't open. Hadrian's gate is just outside. Well worth a visit, especially if you have the 30 euro pass.

title: Interesting site
text: The site is free with the 30 euro pass. It also includes the Tower of the Winds and the Fetiye mosque. We spent an hour or so looking around. It was very interesting. At night you can get some very nice photos of the agora from outside, as the ruins are lit up.

title: Worth a visit
text: This is free with the 30 euro pass. It is worth a visit, and read the info boards, as they explain where the library is and what it was used for. We spent an hour looking around.

title: Interesting
text: This is an octagonal tower that has carvings on the outside depicting the various winds and housed a water clock, but there was no explanation about what the clock looked like or how it worked. The tower is in the Romans agora so it's worth a look, especially if you have the 30 euro pass. The museum of ancient Greek technology has an example of a water clock, which is also worth a visit.

title: Nice
text: We stopped to have a look at this on our way to the Temple of Olympian Zeus. It definitely worth a visit and a photo. The classic shot is with the Parthenon in the background through the arch. It can be busy, so you may need to queue to get the shot, but in October it wasn't busy due to covid. It's the same Hadrian as the one who built the wall!

title: Not much to look at
text: We had the 30 euro pass so this was free. Mildly interesting but not a great deal of information. Other sites were very good with info boards. It was a pleasant walk, and there was a sculpture show next door, so enjoyed it but wouldn't make a special trip to go there.

title: Amazing
text: I would recommend watching the changing of the guard at the Presidential palace rather than the Syntagma square. It's not on a major road junction and it's a lot quieter, so you don't have to compete with other tourists to get a good view. It's free and happens every hour.

title: Interesting
text: We were exploring Philopappos hill, so had a look. 3 padlocked caves that Socrates may have stayed in. If was interesting, but probably not worth a special trip.

title: Great views
text: We visited in October during covid. The views from here are fantastic, and it was nice to get a walk in the hills away from the hussle and bussle of the city. We actually walked around this hill and the surrounding area 3 times, during the morning, afternoon and evening. Great place for photos of the Parthenon.

title: Very pleasant walk
text: We visited in October during covid. It wasn't crowded and we were exploring. Great views and nice to chill and relax away from the crowds in the city. Worth it if you have time to kill.

title: Very interesting
text: We visited in October during covid. We visited on a Sunday morning and it wasn't crowded. We spent at least an hour looking round, with the self guided audio. If you're interested in the Olympics, this is a must.

title: Perfect Base for a tour of Athens
text: We stayed for 5 nights during October whilst covid19 was on. They were the perfect place to stay. They had all the processes in place to stay safe from a covid perspective. They were welcoming and friendly. The roof top restaurant is fantastic - great food, great service and great view of the Parthenon. The location is perfect as well. We could walk to all the tourist sites without using public transport and there were plenty of shops and restaurants within easy reach. We would definitely stay there again when we return to Athens.

title: immaculate
text: This temple is part of the Ancient Agora. It's well worth a visit, especially if you have the 30 Euro tourist ticket. This temple is like the Parthenon but just a smaller version, but virtually intact. We visited during covid19 restrictions, so the site wasn't very busy, but the only entrance that was open was on the north side, not far from the Roman Agora.

title: alley ways, food and shops
text: This area is full of alley ways, shops of all sorts and plenty of food outlets. It's great for meandering around, stumbling on the odd ancient monument and buying souvenirs, clothing, jewellery, leather and stopping for coffee or ice-cream.

title: Fantastic
text: We visited the Acropolis on a monday morning during covid19 restrictions. I'd recommend buying the 30 euro combination ticket and visiting the Acropolis museum before going to the Acropolis. Also, start at the entrance nearest the Acropolis metro station, so you can explore the southern slopes before going to the top of the Acropolis.

title: awesome
text: We went to the Parthenon on a Monday morning, during covid19 restrictions. Buy the 30euro ticket and enter at the entrance nearest the Acropolis metro station. That way you can explore the south slopes before going up the Acropolis to the Parthenon. There was a 1-way system, and it didn't look like you could get to the southern slopes after the Parthenon. It wasn't too busy, but you needed to wear a mask.

title: great museum
text: This museum displays most of the artefacts found at the Acropolis. It took us around 2 hours to go round the museum, and I would definitely recommend going to this museum before visiting the Acropolis itself. We went on a Sunday evening, during covid19, and the museum wasn't very busy.

title: Friendly efficient Transfer from Athens Airport
text:
I booked this transfer from Athens airport to a hotel near the Acropolis partly because the flight left the UK at 6.45 am, so we would've been tired, and partly to avoid public transport due to Covid19. Ioannis was ready and waiting when we arrived at Athens and was friendly and polite. He also gave us a commentary about the sites to see and what to look out for. He even taught us some Greek and recommended some Greek dishes to try! Very professional.
We had intended to get the metro back at the end of our trip, but Ioannis was so good we decided to book a return transfer with him. Would definitely recommend.

title: lovely meal
text: a group of us (4) were going to a show at the Haymarket. We parked st the Haymarket car park. it's a short walk Ask. We ate on a Saturday night. We'd booked, but there was plenty of space. Service was really good and friendly. There was loads of choice on the menu and the food was really good.

title: best Italian in Leicester
text: we went to San Carlos for lunch on a Saturday before going to the comedy festival. There was 4 of us. The food was fantastic. The service was good and the atmosphere was great. The waiters were really nice. We had a fantastic time.

title: great tapas. we were between
text: great tapas. we were between shows at the comedy festival so wanted a quick meal, on a Saturday. The service was great and they were quite quick. The food was really good and the atmosphere was good. They were fairly busy.

title: Scary Mystery
text: This saturday morning, we completed the 'Nerve Klinik' at Break Escape in Loughborough. We've done 'sands of time' and 'boiling point' before, so knew the sort of thing to expect, but the twist with this room is that there was an actor in the room too. Ally was our host and did a fantastic job building the tension before we went in and providing help if we needed it. The room is designed for over 16s, as there's a bit of a horror theme. There's no real danger, and you know the actor won't hurt you, but there is a lot of tension! We completed the task as a group of 4 and had a great time. Would highly recommend it. Ally did a great job. He hosted us for 'Boiling Point' as well, a few months ago. There are 2 more rooms for us to try, so we'll be back soon!

title: Fantastic
text:
We had a fantastic day under ground on the hero extreme trip. There were 5 of us, so we did the trip in slightly less than 6 hours. Our leaders were Jason and Janine, who were both brilliant. The minimum age is 14 and my daughter is 16 and managed easily.
We met up at 9.30 and then walked to the kit room, up a steep track through the middle of a disused slate mine, so a bit loose under foot, so you need trainers. They provide Wellington boots and all safety kit. You have to provide gloves and a packed lunch and drink. Wear something you don't mind getting wet or dirty, although everything we wore was as good as new after being washed. You work reasonably hard and it's 10 degrees C under ground, so you don't need lots of clothes. We had T-shirt and a summer jacket. You will wear a harness, so if you want anything to hand, like a camera, you will need chest pockets. Oh, and you'll need the smallest rucksack that you can get away with for your packed lunch. You stop for a break after a few hours to have lunch.
It's not cheap (£79 per person) but we had a great experience so we think it's worth it. I would definitely recommend it if you are in the area.

title: Great family challenge
text: We walked up the Ranger path and down the Rhyd Ddu path. Both are staight forward -we were novices but reasonably fit. Our youngest person was 15. We parked across the road from the YHA (details are on the website) £6 for all day. We each had a rucksack with food and clothes, although we had more gear than we needed and ended up taking clothing off on the way up as it is hard work. We started at 8.30 and reached the top at around 11.30 without pushing it and having a couple of stops for drink and food. All the paths obviously converge at the top so it was quite crowded. We went up on an early September Saturday so mid week would be less crowded. We hang around the top for almost an hour having more drink and food. The top is about 10°C cooler than the bottom so can be chilly. We had flasks of hot chocolate which was great. You can buy food at the top but it was rammed - we took all our own food and drink. Coming down the Rhyd Ddu path was staight forward. It also took about 3 hours including a couple of stops. At the bottom, to get back to the car park, you can take a bus, a steam train or walk. The bus runs once every 2 hours. We missed it so walked. It took us about half an hour, but is flat. There's no pavement. It's a long day, but well worth the effort.

title: Great day out
text: 4 of us visited here on a cool, windy Saturday. That meant that some monkeys weren't allowed outside, but it was still well worth the visit. There was lots of space and plenty to look at, even the monkeys indoors. We spent an easy day walking around. There wasn't much cover, so it may not have been so nice if it had been raining.

title: A day is not enough
text: We had a great day at the tank museum. 4 of us went on a Friday during the school summer holidays. We got there shortly after 10.00 and it was starting to get busy, but there was plenty of space. The best place to start is 'the tank story' exhibit, which tells a chronological story of why the tank was invented and how it evolved into the tank of today. Then 'the French Experience', 'Tank Men' and 'Battlegroup Afghanistan' are fascinating. The main exhibit is second world war tanks and there's really too much to see in a day and take it all in. Everything was really interesting. The ticket gives free admission for 12 months. It's worth every penny!

title: Comfortable boat trip
text: We wanted to spend a day wandering around Brown's each island, so used the ferry, which was good. They give a bit of a commentary and you can stay on if you just want a boat trip and not go to the island. It cost £12 per adult.

title: Lovely peaceful day
text:
We caught the 10.30 ferry from Poole and spent all day strolling around the island, getting back around 3.00. We walked clockwise and took a picnic with us and ate it on a beach just after the scout camp. It was very peaceful and we hardly saw anyone until we started getting close to the church on our way back. We went on an overcast Thursday during the school holidays.
There are a number of self guided tours, for all ages, so fun for all the family!
It's a National Trust site, and there are quite a few in the area, so it may be worth becoming a member?

title: Well worth a visit
text: Fort Henry is free and a 5 minute walk from the middle beach car park. It's where the king, Churchill, Montgomery and Eisenhower watched training for the Dday landings. It's just a concrete bunker so not an interesting building but is interesting historically. You also get great views of Studland bay.

title: Lovely beach
text:
Middle beach is narrow so I expect it can get busy. We went on a Wednesday in August and it was fine. The beach is sheltered and the sea shallow so it's great for swimming and for kids, although not much room to play on the beach. There are sand dunes east of Knoll beach that would be great for kids.
There's a cafe for sandwiches and icecream, and fort Henry is a 5 minute walk away if you need a break from the beach. Harry's rocks are about 40 minster walk away. Car park is £4 for 4 hours or £9 all day.

title: Lovely beach
text:
We spent the day at middle beach on a Wednesday during the school holidays. The beach is narrow so there's not masses of space, but the bay is sheltered and the water shallow so it's great for swimming. Further along the beach at Knoll it was very busy, but I think I would recommend parking st the Knoll car park and heading left when you get to the beach to avoid the crowds. You can then also explore the sand dunes.
When we went, the ferry wasn't working (it's expected to be out of action until November 2019) so that may be why the beach was quieter nearer the ferry.
Parking was £4 for 4 hours, or £9 all day. Free for National Trust members. There's a few NT places around do may be worth being a member.

title: Nice steam railway
text: £60 for 4 adults. Park at Norden for £3.50 all day. Stop at Corfe castle to look around that then continue to Swanage for lunch. The whole journey is about 20 minutes, so £15 per person is a bit steep.

title: Great lunch
text: It's a short walk from the castle entrance, but far enough to avoid most of the crowds. They had a lovely beer garden, where we had burgers and cider. Lovely food in a peaceful setting!

title: Interesting castle in a great setting
text: We parked in the NT car park (£2 for 2 hours or £4 for 4 hours) and then walked 10 minutes to the castle. It cost £60 for 4 adults. The castle was interesting but had been demolished the civil war, so there wasn't a whole lot to look at. We spent about an hour going around the castle, so was a bit over priced for what it was. With hind site, we should have parked at Norden, £3.50 all day, got the train to Corfe for the castle, then continued to Swanage for lunch, and join the National Trust.

title: Bit expensive
text: We turned up on a Sunday evening around 6.30 and got a table for 6 without a booking. The food was good and the menu a bit more interesting than some of the other restaurants in the area. However, it's a bit expensive. It cost £200.

title: Good shopping centre
text: There's a wide choice of shops and restaurants at this shopping centre. Should be able to get anything you want!

title: Very interesting
text: We visited HMS Warrior on a Sunday morning in August during the summer holidays. We probably started around 10.30. It took us about an hour and a half to go round the ship. We had a leaflet to explain areas of interest around the ship, and there were people dotted around to add some more insight, which were very good. There is no set route around the ship, like there is around Victory or Mary Rose, so it's a bit random as you explore the ship.

title: Really interesting
text: 4 of us, 2 parents and 2 adult children, went round HMS Victory on a Sunday morning whilst spending the day at the Historic Docks. We went in at around 11.30 and there were no queues. We came out about an hour and a half later and there were lots of queues, so get there early to avoid the crowds. The audio is very good, and the route is well organised so you can take your time or scoot round quickly. Dotted around there were a number of people in character who were very knowledgeable and helpful if you had any questions. If you're spending time at the Docks, going round the Victory is a must.

title: Great day out
text: We bought the all in ticket as we were in Portsmouth for 3 days, so would be able to go back if we wanted. We visited the warrior and the victory before lunch and then the submarine museum and harbour cruise after lunch. That was long enough for one day. There is plenty to do at the Historic Docks so although the all in ticket isn't cheap, it's actually good value, unless you're only there for one day. Note that the Mary Rose is on a separate ticket.

title: Average
text: We were 4 adults having an early evening meal on a Monday. We had whitebait, pitta bread and humous for starter and battered haddock and chips and sticky glazed pork for main. For dessert we had pavlova, chocolate tart and cheese board. Food was okay but nothing special. The chips were a bit soggy. All in the meal cost £120 which seemed a bit steep.
